KEEPING BASINGSTOKE BLUE
Thanks to the Conservative-led council, the priorities we want to achieve for our residents, businesses and our borough over the next four years are:
- a place where people can live happily
- a borough where the environment can flourish
- a council that provides good quality services for our residents.
Staying In Touch With You
Basingstoke Conservatives are active on behalf of Basingstoke residents all year round, not just at election time. We live in a democracy, so not every ward has a Conservative representative in local government, but we do our best to provide a Conservative candidate in every ward at every local election so that those who support Conservative values have the choice of voting Conservative.
We would like to do more to keep in touch with the voters right across the town, but it's not always easy to find sufficient people to deliver leaflets in every ward. If you haven't seen a Conservative InTouch for a while, it's probably because we need your help to get our messages out. Please use the Contact button if you would like to help us or know someone else who might.
Find your ward information from the left-hand column of this page.

Local MP Maria Miller met Head Teacher Nathan Gazzard, staff and members of the School Council when she visited Chiltern Primary School, rated 'Good' by Ofsted. Maria wants every school in Basingstoke to be 'Good' or Outstanding'.
Maria said, "Chiltern is yet another Basingstoke school already rated 'Good' or 'Outstanding' by OFSTED, along with 85% of all schools in our community, something other communities can only dream of but I want to be even more ambitious to make sure every child has the opportunity to reach their full potential. Basingstoke's schools have worked hard to achieve higher OFSTED ratings and higher examination results, giving more children the opportunity to get the best results."
Maria said, "The Leadership and teaching at Chiltern means children and families are getting the support they need to succeed.

Local MP Maria Miller recently visited the Sexual Health (Genito-Urinary Medicine) Clinic at Basingstoke and North Hampshire Hospital, to hear about their work. Maria was shown around the Clinic by the Practice Manager, Steve Day, and also met members of the Clinic’s staff, as well as representatives from BRASACC (Basingstoke Rape and Sexual Abuse Crisis Centre. The Mayor of Basingstoke and Deane, Cllr David Leeks, was also visiting the Clinic.
Maria said: “The Clinic plays an important role in helping people with sexual health problems, including sexually transmitted infections and HIV/AIDS. They also work with people of all ages to provide information and advice.”
She added: “I was particularly interested to hear about the Clinic’s absolute commitment to total confidentiality for its clients. I would urge anyone who is concerned about their sexual health to visit the Clinic, knowing that they will receive a confidential and caring service.”
Information about the Clinic’s opening hours and contact details can be found on the Basingstoke and North Hampshire Hospital website - http://www.northhampshire.nhs.uk/our-services/a-z-clinical-services/sexual-health-genito-urinary-medicine-gum/

Arun, having made Basingstoke his home for the past 15 years with his wife and two daughters has gained a deep understanding of the needs of this town.
An alumna of University of Winchester, his professional role as an Information Security Expert is one of the important business sectors here in Basingstoke.
He is an award-winning community champion and leader featured on BBC whose ability to bring people together and drive change is truly remarkable and exemplary.
He is passionate about supporting Basingstoke's diverse communities in fostering a better borough for all. He's proven to be a team player and a leader who can engage and pursue agendas to fruition.
Why you should VOTE FOR ARUN MUMMALA NENI?
DO YOU HAVE A POSTAL VOTE?
The deadline to apply for a postal vote in England for the elections on 6th May 2021 is 5pm on Tuesday 20th April 2021. You must also be registered to vote by midnight on Monday 19th April 2021.

Your Conservative team in Hatch Warren and Beggarwood
Borough Cllrs Rebecca Bean, Samir Kotecha and Dan Putty continue to work for you as well as County Councillor Stephen Reid.
Whether you voted for us or not, we’re here to work for and represent you, the residents of Hatch Warren and Beggarwood. If you have any issues or concerns you’d like us to look into, please get in touch.
You will find more details about us on the Borough website.
As your Conservative team, we bring together parishes, the borough, the county and, with Maria Miller MP, parliamentary experience and resources to make things happen locally.

Basingstoke South West
Stephen Reid
You can find his details at Hampshire County Council.
Stephen Reid is one of the most experienced Councillors in Basingstoke. He is a Cabinet Member at Hampshire County Council, holding the vitally important finance and performance portfolio. He is committed to reducing the County's climate change footprint and has introduced a policy to make all the pool cars at Hampshire electric instead of diesel. He drives an electric car himself.
A past Leader of Basingstoke and Deane Borough Council, Stephen's achievements include building the Anvil and the Leisure Park, and starting festival Place - making Basingstoke a regional centre for arts, leisure and shopping.
Stephen has lived in Basingstoke all his life. He was educated at the local state schools from where he gained a place at Cambridge University and read Economics. He is married and has four grown-up children.

“Basingstoke Foodbank held a Big Collection event on the first weekend of December and it was a pleasure to meet the volunteers, Jane Stubbs the new Chineham Tesco Community Champion and store manager Rosalie Chammas .
The Foodbank Volunteers managed to collect nearly 3000 KG of donations that filled 298 crates from Tesco shoppers during the Big Collection Event for the Foodbank’s Christmas Hamper Project.
Shoppers were given a shopping list of items for the Christmas Hamper Project including Christmas Cake, Yule Long, Sponge Puddings, Christmas Crackers, Seasonal Stuffing and Tinned Meats.
I would like to thank all of those involved in running and supporting the community hubs and Foodbank for their extraordinary efforts in ensuring that those in need of help have been supported. The Foodbank is only made possible because of the time and expertise given by those who run it and the generous donations of residents and businesses. Demonstrating what a strong and resilient community we have here in Basingstoke.”

Maria was welcomed by Stephen Blatchford, owner and CEO, and heard from him about the company’s product manufacture and distribution, and also about its commitment to research and development. Blatchfords has been located in Basingstoke since 1962, and currently employs some 150 staff, with plans to increase this to around 180.
Maria recetly nominated Blatchfords for the Made by Britain project, which aims to showcase the UK’s manufacturing sector.
Maria said: “I am very pleased to visit another successful manufacturing company in Basingstoke. From what I have heard today, the workforce at Blatchfords is highly skilled and it is good to see that they have largely been able to recruit locally for these skilled roles.”
Maria added: “As the Minister for Disabled People, I was particularly interested in the unique support Blatchfords offers to those who have lost a limb. Mobility is a vital part of independence to all of us; by providing prostheses and related services to the people who need them, Blatchfords is helping to improve the quality of many people’s lives.”

Following a welcome from Branch Chairman Tim Colman, Maria spoke about the economic situation and gave an overview of the measures the Government is taking to help small and medium enterprises. She also responded to questions on a range of issues.
Maria said: “We are taking a whole range of actions to help smaller businesses to continue to prosper during these difficult times. These include the “Red Tape Challenge” to try to reduce burden of regulation on business, and new ways in which businesses can access finance and other support.”
Maria added: “The Government’s biggest economic priority is to reduce the deficit and restore stability. Because of the overhang of debt, we have always warned that recovery would be choppy.”
Maria also highlighted the important role that the M3 Local Enterprise Partnership has to play in the growth of local businesses, and applauded them for securing £210,000 from the Government’s Start Up Fund.

Being a member of Basingstoke Conservative Association means that you have joined the most open and democratic political party in Britain.
After the first three months of your membership, you will be entitled to a vote in Party ballots - including the opportunity to vote for the Leader of the Conservative Party. You will also have a chance to influence Party policy by letting us know your views.
Any person living in the United Kingdom is eligible to join the Conservative Party. Applicants are not required to be registered voters or UK nationals. There is no upper or lower age limit on membership, although children under the age of 15 cannot be enrolled as full voting members.
Please use one of the Join on-line buttons on this website.

Maria was welcomed by Tony Reid (Chief Executive), Amanda Quincey (Principal) and Michael del Mar (Chair of Governors) and heard from them about the education, care and therapy that Treloar’s provides for young people with severe and complex disabilities. She also heard about the forthcoming co-location of the College and the School, following the re-development of the Holybourne campus.
Maria was shown around the new buildings, and also visited the Trailblazer unit, which is the UK’s first mobile service that assesses the needs of disabled young people at mainstream and special schools.
Maria said: “I was very pleased to visit the new Treloar campus and hear about the fantastic work Treloar’s is doing to help disabled young people reach their potential.”
Maria added: “I was also really interested to hear about the work placements that the students undertake, the independent living skills programme and the contact between Treloar’s and the local community. All of this is so important in helping the young people to plan for the future.”

MP for Basingstoke Maria Miller spoke in the second reading of the Building Safety Bill on Wednesday. The Building Safety Bill seeks to give residents power to hold developers to account and seek compensation for substandard work. The Bill will also make it easier for homeowners to seek compensation for poor building construction, and will also create a new Building Safety Regulator to ensure the highest safety standards are met for high-rise buildings from design to occupation.
The Bill also creates a new homes ombudsman, which was called for in 2016 by the All-Party Parliamentary Group for Excellence in the Built Environment, in a report that Maria co-chaired after constituents told her of their problems with build quality.
Maria Miller said,
“I welcome the Bill, which requires a fundamental overhaul of our building industry’s attitude towards the quality of new homes. For too long, the biggest five builders have squeezed out smaller local home builders, whose reputation for quality is central to their business. The Bill makes build quality central to everyone’s business. First and foremost, however, we need to speak up for those who have been impacted by the building industry’s current fire safety regulatory failure. Those directly affected by the tragedy at Grenfell are always in our minds, but so are the people who own homes in high-rise flats. They continue to shoulder the worry resulting from construction work that has failed fire safety tests.”
“The Government have acted rapidly, and by putting in place a £5 billion fund to cover remedial works, the Government are clear that they do not want the costs to fall on the shoulders of leaseholders. Building operators have also been able to get in-principle agreements for significant fire safety remedial works, but the worry for residents remains because some building owners might be cautious about starting remedial works without clear sight of what happens if additional problems are discovered. It’s important that the Government give additional assurances so freeholders aren’t able to passing on the cost of remedial works to leaseholders.”
The Building Safety Bill also includes in it provisions from Maria’s 2018 Private Members’ Bill (Fire Safety Information Bill), which required residents of high-rise buildings to be provided with far more fire safety information.
Maria also raised concerns from Basingstoke constituents at debate, including about the complexity of building ownership structures, and the need for personal evacuation plan evaluations that work disabled and vulnerable people in the event of a fire.
To watch Maria’s full contribution, click here: https://parliamentlive.tv/event/index/9a26f78c-9111-4757-8db8-29c04e4e8586?in=18:02:32&out=18:05:40

Lavazza is one of the biggest coffee companies in the world and their UK business to business home is Basingstoke. A family run business with a 3 billion Euro turnover, Lavazza in Basingstoke markets and sells coffee vending machines for the workplaces and offices.
Maria said, "Lavazza's business to business operation is one of Basingstoke's big employers with around 300 employees. Basingstoke’s vibrant local economy is so strong because of the diverse mix of global and local companies to provide high quality jobs for local residents.”
Lavazza has a particular focus on workplace diversity and tackling Modern Slavery in its supply chain. Partnering with ActionAid, Taylors of Harrogate and the Ethical Tea Partnership, Lavazza works with tea farming communities in places across the world to provide the support needed to smallholder tea farmers and workers to have improved living conditions, a positive working environment and work towards freedom from violence and child labour.
Basingstoke has a vibrant economy and is the most productive place in Hampshire and home to around 7,950 businesses on 9,200 different sites, with a diverse range of industry sectors providing jobs at a range of pay scales and skill levels.

Local MP Maria Miller has visited the Vodafone facility in Basingstoke, the location of the criminal attack earlier this year which resulted in widespread loss of mobile network coverage for many hours. During her visit she met Vodafone’s Head of Government Affairs, Paul Morris, and the Head of Security, Mark Hughes, who had travelled from their Newbury headquarters.
Vodafone briefed Maria on the incident in February and the measures they have taken since them to improve both physical security and network resilience.
Maria said: “Vodafone told me that there is nothing more important for the company than keeping the mobile networks up and running for its customers, and that they have taken taken urgent steps to seek to improve their resilience.”
Maria added: “I was pleased to hear that new security measures had been put in place to try to avoid these types of outages in future. This is important not just for individual mobile users, but also for the businesses and services that rely on constant mobile connectivity.”

By joining the Conservative Party, you're doing your bit to help change Britain.
Your support is vital to our campaign to build a better future.
Freedom - Conservatives believe in less interference from the State - freedom for individuals, families, voluntary groups and businesses.
Enterprise - Conservative want to keep taxes low and set businesses free from red tape to help Britain compete in the global economy.
Responsibility - Conservatives stand for the rule of law and support for all members of our society. We recognise our duty to protect the environment for future generations.
Nation - Conservatives want to safeguard the Union of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, maintain strong defence and uphold our right to national self-government. We want to be in Europe but not run by Europe.

Basingstoke MP Maria Miller dropped into the M3 Job Club recently, for an update on the current events and activities at the Job Club from Richard Thayer, who set up the Club earlier this year. The Club meets every Friday at the Innovation Centre on Basing View.
Maria heard that there were now 100 members on the Club’s database, and ten of the members had found a new job since Maria’s last visit to the Club in late June.
Maria said: “It was good to hear that the M3 Job Club is going from strength to strength, in continuing to offer support to those who are out of work in the management and professional sectors. The group, run entirely by volunteers, is helping people get back to work, and also provides support to those thinking about starting up their own business.”
Maria added: “The Club has a really packed programme, including activities to provide members with information, knowledge and advice from professional coaches and business volunteers. They work with a number of businesses in the area, both smaller enterprises and also blue chip companies such as Nokia.”

Maria said, "Last week I visited Arena's newest, state of the art serviced offices ahead of their official opening for business. It was great to see how Arena have invested in our town with the transformation of Grosvenor House in Basing View, which can provide serviced offices for small start-ups or even a whole floor if required".
Fran Williamson from Arena said, “This £12m investment in Basingstoke provides office facilities that any company would be proud to call home, and creates the capacity for businesses to grow, expand and work as flexibly as they need to. Arena’s second centre in Basing View, The Grosvenor complements The Square with gym, coffee shop, terrace, meeting rooms and collaboration space”.
The backbone of Basingstoke's vibrant local economy are small-medium enterprises with over 90% of Basingstoke businesses employing 10 people or fewer. Serviced offices like these are a flexible way of allowing businesses to gradually expand creating more jobs, fostering innovation, and contributing to the unique vibrant character of our town.

Maria said, “As a patron of the Basingstoke & District Disability Forum it was an honour to attend their annual Christmas Party held at Popley Fields Community Centre. A great opportunity to meet so many old friends and to support the important work of the BDDF.”
BDDF Members, volunteers, and carers got into the festive spirit along with special guests the Mayor of Basingstoke & Deane Cllr David Leeks and Mayoress Amanda Leeks.
The BDDF are the disability champions of Basingstoke and offer important support for anyone young or old who are affected by disability in the local community. They aim to promote both visible and non-visible disabilities providing information and awareness by bringing people together. Members are able to access free activities such as yoga to help aid mobility.
It is free to become a member, for more information click here

Basingstoke Conservatives is a voluntary organisation of friends, members and elected representatives, from all walks of life, who work hard for the people of Basingstoke all year round - not just at election time. We have fun together at events, raising money for campaigning, delivering leaflets, talking to residents on the doorstep and getting involved in campaigns. We represent and include people with a diverse range of backgrounds, interests and concerns. We are a broad church, which encourages open debate and accepts differences of opinion.What unites us are the core Conservative values:
Freedom
Conservatives believe in less interference from the State - freedom for individuals, families, voluntary groups and businesses.
Enterprise
Conservative want to keep taxes low and set businesses free from red tape to help Britain compete in the global economy.
Responsibility
Conservatives stand for the rule of law and support for all members of our society. We recognise our duty to protect the environment for future generations.
Nation
Conservatives want to safeguard the Union of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, maintain strong defence and uphold our right to national self-government. We want to be in Europe but not run by Europe.
Join us! Whatever your interests and spare time, your involvement is completely up to you. We’d love to hear from you – why not join us today! Click the Join on-line button on the left.
